div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). div.head: THE AEROPLANE IN LONDON
div.p: A telegram, which we publish in to-day's issue, announces that London has been treated to the wonderful sight of a dirigeable aeroplane circling around St. Paul's Cathedral and paying a surprise visit to the War Office.

Captain Dunn, the son of a distinguished soldier, believing be bad hit upon a suitable design for an aeroplane, or flying machine, submitted his plans and models to the War Office authorities. The experts looked into the project, and leave was given to the captain to proceed with his experiments, more or less at his own expense; but they agreed to lend him assistance in the work with men and officers from one of the Royal Engineers' departments. the ballooning. The secure remoteness of Glen Tilt, with its surrounding hills is admirably suited for the carrying out of experiments. The Dake of Atholl and the Marquis of Tallibardine placed the district at their disposal. To safe. guard the operations from carious and intrusive eyes, keepers were stationed to prevent anyone wandering down the glen or over the neighbouring hills. The high road is public, but as the | highway is ordinarily the low way, nothing can be seen therefrom.

Captain Dunn's machine is a combination of the Albatross-wing type, with guiding pinions, upon which is superimposed a second plane. The driving power is imparted by twin screws, or propellers, placed upon either side. The screws are set in motion by a 8-cylinder, French made motor engine, Unfortunately, at present the engine does not give altogether satisfactory results. The course of experiments were begun by launching the loaded machine from the hill-sides, to see how it would go. Many long and successful flights were made in that way, whilst the inventor and his helpers, by their constant practice, came to know daily more and more of the mysterious trieks of the air. In one of the flights the apparatus when launched took & downward dip and ran upon a dyke. It was much damaged, but in a short time the framework was repaired, the cloth was stitched again, and further trials made of a more fortunate nature. These confirmed the inventor and his friends in their hopes for the future of the machine, but all aeroplanes require a constant guiding touch. Unless kept on their true course they eventually flounder and fail. It is so with Captain Dunn's machine. The pinions and deflecting planes, otherwise the wings and sail of the bird, have to be actuated by an instant and skilled touch, to meet the variations of air currents and the deviations occurring in flight. It has been found that this can be done, and Captain Dunn and his assistants have been able on repeated occasions to fly for a considerable distance about Glen Tilt. Latterly the three-cylinder air-cooled motor has been attached to the apparatus, and still longer flights have been achieved. To see these later trials the chief of the balloon establishment came down. He has expressed his satisfaction at the results accomplished and the opinion that still more could be done with an engine capable of developing more power.

There have been no serious mishaps since an occasion when the aeroplane smashed itself against the wall, and but for the uncertainty connected with the running of the engine, flights of several miles could have been made. There is always the difficulty in aeroplanes of safely rising from the ground, unless they are launched from some elevated position. Trouble is equally grave to ensure their coming down to rest without getting broken in alighting, but the Dupn machine has behaved in these respects remarkably well, though it may be necessary by and by to attach to all aeroplanes serews worked perpendicularly, to lift them as well as to lower them from or back to the ground. The framework and wings are calculated to sustain a weight when soaring of over half a ton. The frame is strongly lashed and stayed, and the apparatus can be run forward upon light wheels. The experimentalists have a secluded camp, in which they live and work. There is still much to be done to perfect the apparatus, but something of real im. portance has been accomplished towards solving the problem of flight in bodies heavier than air.

div.head: Sudan Government Railways
div.p: The Khartoum Railway line will be open for traffic from to-day.

div.head: Arrival of Troops.
div.p: General Bullock inspected this morning the fresh troops which arrived by the transport Sicilia."

div.head: Ramadan.
div.p: The Government office hours during the month of Ramadan will be from 10 am, to 1 p.m. daily

div.head: Police Budget.
div.p: 3 thefts, 20 misdemeanours and 106 contraventions have taken place in Cairo during the last 24 hours.

div.head: Egyptian Army
div.p: Bimbashi Coke, of the 10th Sudanese, has been struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army from the 20th ult.

div.head: Police Appointment
div.p: Mr. Philips, who has had 20 years' experience in this country, has been appointed Maowen of police for the Esbekieh Caracol.

div.head: Commencement of Tourist Season.
div.p: A party of 24 tourists arrived this morning by the S.S. “Cleopatra” and left for Cairo at 8 a.m. by special train from the Custom House Station.

div.head: A Native's Suicide
div.p: A native, named Mohammed Mustapha, hanged himself to the ceiling of his room in Haret el Sharia, Cairo, during the early hours of Saturday morning.

div.head: The Pilgrim Season.
div.p: The number of Pilgrims who traversed the Snow Canal during the last week of September amounted to 1840, of whom only 60 were Egyptians.

div.head: Collapse of a House.
div.p: A house in the Geit el Edda, Cairo, collapsed in Cairo on Saturday and buried its occupants, one of whom died from injuries received from the debris.

div.head: The Amateur Race Meeting.
div.p: At the conclusion of the race-meeting held on the A.S.C. course on Saturday, & camera was found. Owner can have same on application at the “Egyptian Gazette" office.

div.head: Threatened strike Averted.
div.p: The auto-garage dispute is at an end, the Greeks who caused the trouble having been dismissed, and English heads, with a staff of natives under them have been appointed in their stead

div.head: Medical Licenses.
div.p: he Ministry of the Interior has granted a license to Dr. James Graham Willmore to practise as a physician, and to Mr. Gregory Hatzkelevitch Flexer to practise as a dentist in Egypt.

div.head: The Rodah Bridge
div.p: The bridge is practically finished, and is to be tested probably on the 8th inst. but it will not be opened until the roads at the other side are finished, work which will probably take some time

div.head: Sugar from Batavia
div.p: The S.S. "Dardanus” expected to arrive at Suez on or about the 11th inst; is bringing a large consignment of Batavia gar for, account of the Sucreries of Egypt. This is the first consignment arriving from Batavia since the failure of this company

div.head: The Sudan Government.
div.p: Major Turner, director of the Sudan Postal and Telegraph services, has arrived in Cairo from Khartoum to confer with Bernard Pasha concerning the budget for next year. It is again rumoured that the Government offices of the Sudan will be transferred from Cairo to Khartoum

div.head: Italy to Red Sea
div.p: Our Suez correspondent reports that the Florio-Rubattino Company, which intended to establish from the 14th inst a regular monthly service between Italy and the Red Sea ports, has renounced for the second time this project, apparently not having come to an milerstanil ing with the Italian Government

div.head: Cairo Postal Administration
div.p: "Would it be too much to ask the Postal Administration to put the painters to work on the street boxes in Cairo," asks a correspondent. At present the majority of such boxes are of the same dull colour as the houses against which they stand, and this, though it may be harmonious, is certainly not attractive. Indeed it is always with a vague feeling of distrust that one drops a letter into their gloomy depths so wholly do they seem to have become a part of the forgotten past.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter

div.head: CRIME IN THE PROVINCES
div.p: A MONTH'S MURDERS.

Attention has frequently been paid in the columns of the “Egyptian Gazette" to the alarming number of crimes which is committed in the provinces of Egypt, and the still more disquieting fruitlessness of the efforts made by the authorities of the interior to ensure the public safety outside the principal towns of the country. Lawlessness, we are told by many of our provincial readers, almost reigns supreme, and officialdom, it is alleged, is becoming a hotbed of corruption and bribery. We trust that increased efforts will be made by the Government to put an end to what is undoubtedly a most serious evil, though perhaps exaggerated to a certain ex: tent by some. Those qualified to express an opinion by their long residence in the country assure us that the only method to adopt for the extermination of crime is to largely increase the number of English officials in the provinces, and to place them in charge of Modifiers and Markazes, and this measure, we are assured, would be welcomed by Native and European alike. A true charge of murder is seldom sustained against the murderer, who always manages to secure six or seven | alibis. During last month twenty-three mur ders were registered in the Markaz of Menouf, Menoufieh Moudirieh, the last orime being tha murder by the omdeh of Gezai by his unele. After death the man was announced by the Government doctor to have died from apoplexy, but on an English inspector being called in it was found that the man had been shot through the head! The omdeh was placed under arrest and taken to Shibin el Kom for trial

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of the commencement of the month of Ramadan H.H. the Khedive will hold to-morrow a reception at Ras-el Tin, to take place in the following order:
8 p.m. - The Ulema ; the Princes of the Khədivial Family; the heads of State administrations
8.30 p.m.-The magistrates of the Mixed Tribunals; the magistrates of the Native Tribunals; the officers of the Army and Navy of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards ; the civil officials

9p.m.--Civil and military non officials, with the ranks of Lewa or Oula Sinf Sarri, and 'upwards ; officers of the Army and Navy retired or en disponibilité, with the rank of Miralai or Kaimakam ; non-official Beys with the rank of Moutemaiz or Sanieh; the members of the Municipal Commission.
9.30 p.m. -Native merchant's; the civil and military household of H.H. the Khedive and the Khedivial Khassa.

The reception is exclusively reserved for persons resident at Alexandria. The Military will attend in undress uniform and civilians in frockets (redingotes). Civil officials admitted to this reception must have at least the rank of sub-director (or an equivalent rank) and the grade of Sanieh or Kaimakam (military), as well as magistrates dominated by decree. Her Highness the Khedivah will receive the same day, between 8 and 10 pm, the Priecesses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies only.

div.head: THE SIRDAR'S ARRIVAL
div.p: Sirdar Sir Reginald Prancis Wingate Pasha and Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha, InspectorGeneral of the Sudan, arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S. "Cleopatra" from Trieste. They were met at the quay by Ayoub Bey, sub-director of Customs, and a guard of honour drawn from the mounted police force and commanded by Kaimakas Rundle Bey.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S HEALTH
div.p: We are glad to learn that the health of Lord Cromer has been steadily improving, and that he has much benefited by his holiday and rest in Scotland. He has now returned to London, and those interested in Egypt are looking forward to the end of the month when the Corporation of london are about to confer upon him the great honour of inscribing his name amongst the role of royalties, great statesmen, and warriors who have received the the freedom of the City. The ceremony is to take place at the Guildhall on the 28th of October next.

With reference to the paragraph appearing in our issue of the 23rd September which stated that Lord Cromer was coming to Egypt, this was a printer's error, the paragraph referring, of course, to the Sirdar. Lord Cromer, whilst taking a lively interest in things appertaining to Egypt, has no intention of visiting this country, all events for the present.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: The pilgrims, who arrived this morning at Alexandria from Constantinople by the Khedivia Mail 8.8. "Ismailia"are the last to be allowed to set foot here and extraordinary precautions are being taken to prevent them having as little communication as possible with the outside world during their journey from this port to Suey After having been disem barked they were pnt into a special train and sent to Suez in quarantine under & police guard. There a steamer of the Khedivial Line is awaiting them and on their arrival they will be at once sent on board the steamer.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE
div.p: THE IMPORT. POSITION

A marked improvement is reported in the import trade during the last month and especially during the past fortnight. Relieved of the reckless and unhealthy competition which culminated in the large failures of the early summer, stocks of Madchoster goods in bond, which had accumulated and increased by forty per cent between May and August, have now been reduced to about the level of May.
The old import houses are gradually inducing a return to the system of four months credit which had during the period of inflated imports been extended with disastrous results to seven months.
The coal trade is also satisfactory and under threats of stoppage of supplies, buyers in the interior have found money which they had previously declared improeurable to meet their engagements.
Advice from Manchester reports a good demand for cotton goods for China, Japan and India and exporters of cotton from Egypt anticipate satisfactory prices during the season.

The trade of the country is therefore, as we have maintained throughout the period of the late crisis, perfectly healthy, and the effects of the crisis on the Bourse will gradually disappear. The Statist has recently found occasion to lecture the banking community of London on their imperfect knowledge of their business and if some of the fraternity here will condescend to learn the alphabet of their business we may be spared & recurrence of the foolish but disastrous panic of the summer.
AN EXCELLENT MEASURE.

In pleasing contrast the following announcement will be read by the mercantile community as showing the intelligent appreciation of their needs by the financial advisers of the Government, and their readiness in conjunction with the National Bank of Egypt to give all practical assistance. In former years the money paid into the Caisse de la Dette for the land tax, which comes in chiefly at this time of the year, was accumulated in actual specie at the Mondirieh towns and afterwards remitted in /specie periodically to Cairo. Further delay usually took place there and it was probably several weeks from the date that the gold left the fellahs' hands until it was again available for circulation. Under the new arrangement whenever a sum of L.E. 1,000 has accumulated at any Modified towns, it is paid into the local branches of the National Bank of Egypt. The bank is in a position to utilise this same gold within a few days of its having left the pockets of the fellaheen.
THE COTTON CROP & GOLD IMPORTS.

The outflow of gold to Egypt has begun, remarks the "Globe," and next month the cotton crop will begin to come forward. The extent of the crop has not been estimated. What is definitely known, however, is that the ares soWD was larger than previously, and as weather and other conditions have been favourable, it is fair to assume that Egypt's cotton yield will this year be of record dimensions. In the circumstances, it is reasonable to look for a considerable trade revival. As a matter of fact, trade is not really bad now, the recent crisis having been almost entirely due to inordinate Stock Exchange gambling. The young men with £12 to £20 a month who, on the arrival of the crash, were found balls of soores of thousands of pounds worth of inflated securities will find their credit extinguished, or vastly limited, and will not be able to play again a role so dangerous to the general interest of the Egyptian public. Yesterday, we pointed out that the weak bull has his nses; but he can well be dispensed with after a campaign has fairly started, and he pnagent to be shaken out without compunction when it is quite evident that capital has followed his lead. It may be roughly reckoned that the moving of the cotton crop will mean the influx of about £25,000,000 to Egypt. In spite of the concealment of gold by the fellaheen, this sum of money cannot fail to exercise a beneficial effect on trade and industry in the land of the Pharaohs. Anglo-Egyptians now leaving for Cairo are uniformly optimistic, and better and busier times are predicted for the coming season.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM
div.p: The cotton worm may now be said to be exterminated throughout the country and the fight against this destructive pest to be over, only to be renewed, however, we presume, with equal energy, and we trust with similar success, next season. The official bulletin reports that in the provinces of Assiout, Behers, Beni-Sonef, Fayoum, Gharbieh, Ghizeh, Mengufieh, Minieh, Keneb, and Sharkleh there was no appearance of the worm during last week. In Dakahlieh province one fedden was infected and cleared, and in Kalioubieh 32 feddaus were infected and cleared.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Roman Prince,” with passengers and general cargo left Malta on the 5th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Wednesday the 9th October
The Ellerman līner "City of Oxford”, sailed hence for Liverpool direct yesterday morning, with a full cargo, including, 5,920 bales of cotton
The Moss liner "Menepthah” arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltan, Algiers,

div.head: THE SCORPION DANGER
div.p: EFFECTIVE SERUM PREPARATION

In consequence of numerous deaths which occur annually in Egypt as the result of scorpion stings, the Department of Public Health has taken up the preparation of serum, Auli Boorpique." This serum which is analogous to the serum “Auli Venimeux," of Dr. Calmette, is prepared by the repeated injections of horses with the poison obtained from scorpiotis, beginning with a very small quantity, increasing it gradually until the animal is fit to support the poison of five or six hundred scorpions at one dose. As horses are gery susceptible to the poison, the operation takes a long time and should be made with great precaution. The serum of borse's blood which has been treated in this manner will completely centralise the poison of a scorpion sting, in such a manner that if the servin; and poison are mixed together, the combination would be absolutely non-poisonous. In the case of a person or animal stung by a scorpion, the serum should be immediately applied to the affected part, the effect of the poison being neutralised as soon as it comes in contact with the serum. It is important that the application of the serum should be made as soon as possible after the sting in order to prevent the poison passing into the circulation of the blood.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB. ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The final shoot for the III Class Challenge Cup presented by the 1st Batt, Royal Dublin Fusiliers and the Semi Final in the Champion Cups Competition, were held last Saturday, The scores in both these competitions show marked improvement, generally, our last years' results.
The winner of the III Class Challenge Cup is Mr. J. O. Donovan. The total number of members who shot was 21.

div.head: ATTEMPTED BANK BURGLARY.
div.p: Writing under date of the 5th inst., Santa correspondent reports that at 9-3 p.m. the previous evening an attempt was made to break into the Agricultural Bank Agency by a gang of burglars. A window at the back of the building was forced open, but the bank ghaffir, awakened by the noise, fired several shots and brought down one of the men with a wound in the thigh. The noise caused by the encounter attracted a crowd of people and the mamour was quickly on the scene to conduct investigation.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil has returned to Cairo from Alexandria
Mr. Webb, Under Secretary of State, Ministry of Public Works, is expected to arrive at | Alexandria from Europe to-morrow.
Among those who arrived this morning by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. "Cleopatra were Dr. Grabem Bey, Dr. Raffer and Mr. Wells.
Mr. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul General at Alexandria, is returning from Italy on the 21st inst.
Mr. David Rees, director of Reuter's Cairo Agency, has returned from leave.
Mr. and Miss Lias, of the Victoria College, Arrived this morning by the Moss liner "Menepthah"
The Ministry of Interior has approved of the transfer of George Bey Mikhail, Secretary of the Sharkieh Moudirieh to Assiout, and Gates Bey from Minieh to Dakshlieh

We regret to announce the death of Signor Alfredo Serafini, a much respected member of the Italian community for Allanrid, who passed away yesterday afternoon at Ruleb. The funeral will take place at four oclock this afternoon.
Mr. R.G. Hawkins, the Secretary of the Eighty Club is staying for a few days at the New Khedivial Hotel, on his way to London from S. Africa.

At all Souls' Church, South Hampstead, on Saturday week, the wedding took place of Mr. Hylton Burleighi Dale, of 60, Onslow-gardens, South Kensington, and Miss Selnia Kapar, only child of the late Mr. Michel Koper, of Tibby, Cairo: (who served as chief in| terpteter on the staff of Lord Wolseley in the expedition to liselieve Gotion at Khartoum), and niece Tof the late Mgr. Joneph Kasprian, Patriarch of Armenie The Rev. GB. Terry. Vion of All Bonle, ofheiated. Mr. Ibrahim Sabundje, an old friend of the family, gave the bride away. She was married in a gowa of rich, Oriental exam satin trimmed with lace and chiffon, and lace veiloves swath of orange blossom. There were only two bridesmaids, Miss Muriel Hall and Miss Violet Sabundje. Mr. Algernon Barolay Dale (brother of the bridegroom) was best man. The reception was held at the Whamcliffe Roongs. The honeymoon will be spent in Bohemia.

div.head: MR. MITCHELL INES'S MEMOIRS.
div.p: It is said that Mr. Mitchell Innes intends compiling the memoirs of his career. The work should be of great interest an account of the Cpomeric Age. We have been unable to obtain any confirmation of this report which appears in our contemporary, “LA Reforme." The following is a translation of the passage:

We understand that the departure of Mr. Mitchell Innes from Egypt, which has been decided in principle sing the beginning of this summer, will take place before the end of the year. Nobody knew yet what new post this distinguished official will be called upon to occupy, but it is settled that he will take pne of the most important, pook in the diplomatic service. It is, however, Announced that Mr. Mitchell Innes will not atol once return to an active career as he has the intention to enjoy a well-deserved repose in his native land and he will employ his leisure time in writing hist oins It is certain that this work, the publication of which will be eagerly awaited will be of extraordinary interest We hope to have further and more precise details on this subject."

div.head: THE PASHA'S PROTEST.
div.p: We have received the following letter from General Ahmed Djellaleddin Pasha

Monsieur le Directeur Casa de Pkgyptian Gazette." Le résumé que "Agence Reuter donne de ma lettre au Times dans une dépeshe datie dų 4 de ce fois contient quelques inexactitudes que je tiens à rectifier. 1 Cette lettre ne constitue pas un avertissement à l'adresse de Gouvernement Ottoman. Elle contient une exposition de la situation en Turquie destinée faire comprendre à V Europe Minjastice et le danger résultant de la partialité dont elle fait preuve dans l'euvre de réforme qu'elle sherohe à introduire dans ce pays. A Ma lettre ne dit nullement que les Turos auront recours à des violences extrêmes si les Chretiens de Y Empire ne sont pas réforthes". Me dit qu ayant déjà commencé s'agiter contre les autorités sous infidonde de leurs propres souffranoes les Toros pourraient se porter des extrémités dans cette voie, si une amélioration ne se produit pas dans leur siLogo tuation.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à mid:)

Encore une preuve que notre place a besoin de l'appui du Stock Exchange pour aller de l'avant; à peine une réaction s'est-elle produite à Londres, qu'un mouvement analogue s'est déolaré ioi. Nos valeurs dirigeantes sont totalement délaissées à des prix en baisse sur ceux de vendredi dernier. Cela ne veut pas dire que l'animation ait fait défant : il y a en autant de brait que d'habitude et pour les non-initiés la séanoe a dû paraitre asgez bonne. Ce sont les spéculateurs & courte échéance qui opèrent presque erclusivement. Leurs efforts ont porté ce matin en Nungovich Hotels, Estates, Delta Land, United et Comptoir. Il y a eu également de la demande en Bébéra mais sans affaires. Ce sont les Nungovich qui ont surtout absorbé l'attention générale : leur courg a été poussé de 15 1/2 a 17; ce qui n'a d'ailleurs pas trop éproaxé les acheteurs, car on se tient généralement sur la réserve : on évalue à 2 ou 300 au maximum le nombre de ces titres qui ont changé de mains. Au début la National Bank avait aussi donné lieu a quelques petites transactions, pour se ralentir ensuite et terminer dépréciée. On a constaté d'ailleurs que la tenue en général était beancoup mieux à l'ouverture qu'en oldtare. Il a été venda aux enchères publiques 300 Estates à 11/16 et 150 Building Lands à 2 1/16. La tendance est hésitante, les acheteurs se tenant sur la réserve. - . L'Agricole, fléchit de 8.5/16 À 8 1/4, la National Bank de 22 1/16 à 21 7/8, la Delta Light de 10 1/2 à 10 3/8, la Daira de 13 5/8 à 18 1/2. Seule l'Obligation Crédit Poncier Egyptien progresse de 300 à 301. En baisse encore les Eaux du Caire de 112 à 111, et leg Splendid Hotels de 4 1/2 X 4 3/8. La Béhéra avance, au contraire, de 20 5/8 à 21 1/8 sons l'effet d'une demande, et la Banque d'Orient s'améliore légèrement de 119 1/2 à 120. Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, les Markets rétrogradent de 27/9 & 27/6, les Batates de 11/16 à 21/32, l'United de 11/32 # 5/16 et l'Investment de 17/32 á 1/2, tandis que la Cassa di Sconto reprend de 44 à 44 1/2, la Delta Land de 1 11/16 à 1 8/4, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21 à 21/8, la fondateur Comptoir do 1 13/16 à 1 7,8, et l'Aboukir de 28/3 & 28/6. Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changement à signaler. Comme on le voit, à part les Nungovich Hotels, les variations sont peu importantes et indiquent platot une baisse. Quant aux affaires, elles sont presque nulles, même sur les valeurs abordées. Les dépêches nous apprennent que la Ban que d'Angleterre vient d'expédier en Egypte 1,200,000 livres. C'est l'envoi le plus important que nous ayons eu depuis le commencement de la saison cotonnière.

div.head: CHILD BIRTH AND KIDNEY DISEASE
div.p: BODY BLOATED WITH DROPSY.

Mrs. W. Brown, 5, South-Western Cottages, Dorchester, England, says: "For fifteen years I suffered with my kidneys. It started with a confinement and every confinement after wards left me worse than before. My back gave me the most trouble ; across the small part of it was a dreadful feel. ing, just as it a knife were being put into my back, the pain taking my breath away. I did not know how to turn over in bed or how to get up in the mornings, for there was always * gnawing ache in my back, and the least cold would settle there.

The urinary secretions were in a dreadful condition. They caused awful pain, and sometimes I was unable to pass them. I became very much bloated in the body, legs and face, and there were bags of water under my eyes, making them very tender. I was unable to fasten up my clothes properly because of the swellings.

"I decided to try Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and noticed relief soon after I began using them, the first benefit being that I awoke feeling free of pain, and with an appetite. Keeping on with the pills the pains grew less frequent, I felt better in myself, and the kidney secretions became clear and natural. Now I am feeling absolutely well - it is the first spell of good health I have had for fifteen years. My care is all the more wonderful because my complaint is inherited, being a family one
(Signed) W. Brown."
Going on for six months later a representative called to see her. "My health is first rate," said Mrs. Brown. "My cure is a lasting one. Friends say to me, "Why, you look younger instead of older.'

Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box, or 71 P.T. for 6 boxes ; or they may be had direct from the agents for Egypt, Mr. E. Del Mar, Rue Hotel du Nil, and Rue Mousky, Cairo : Rue Tewfik, (opposite the Bourse), Alexandria, and Rae Commerciale, Port Said ; and Messers S. Fischer, and Co., Roe Sheriff Pacha, Alexandria.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de 200 regårds de visite en fonte et 400 grilles de puisards conformément aux dessins et spécifications du cahier des charges. Le cautionnement est fixé à LEg. 75. Le cabier des charges est déposé au burean Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté A Monsiear l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 22 Octobre 1907. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. Lenveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion: Soumission pour fourniture de regards de visite en fonte et grilles. Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions de cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 22 Octobre à midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée
Alexandrie le 2/10/07. Le Vice-Président 31037-3-3 (signé) Dr SCHIESS.

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH CO. LTD.
div.p: AVERAGE TIME occupied in transmission of Egyptian telegrams from England to Alexandria on Tuesday, 11th July, 1905.
OUTWARDS.
Between the hours of 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. (Cairo time)

Mr. Winston Churchill, replying to the elected councillors' request for increased popular representation, said that the Government desired to associate the Maltese with the administration of their own affairs. He would give fall weight to the advice of the elected councillors, but he recalled the anti-Government action of the councillors in 1902 which was incompatible with the orderly Government necessary in a great fortress. Unless there was evidence of the non-recurrence of such an incident it would be impossible to re-open the Constitutional question. (Reuter)

div.head:
SOCIALISM IN GERMANY.
THE COLONY QUESTION.

div.p: The Socialist leader Bernstein, in an article to the "Vorwaerts," attacks the section of Socialists desirons of discarding the Colonies and making immature communities self-governing. He would never, he said, dream of giving the Bengalees the political rights enjoyed by the Canadians. He cites British rule in Egypt as the most successful example of humane colonisation.(Reuter)

div.head:
MULEY HAFID'S SUPPORT
IMPORTATION OF ARMS.

div.p: T2,600 fresh volunteer horsemen have joined Muley Hafid's Marrakesh and Hafido followers, who are so numerous that he is unable to arm them all. The new Governor of the town has succeeded in removing a quantity of arms from the Custom House and sending them to Mulay Hafid.(Reuter)

div.head:
THE MACRODONIAN QUESTION
RUMOURED SECRET CONVENTION.

div.p: It is reported that the Grand Duke Vladimir has concluded a secret military RussoBulgarian convention concerning Macedonia. (Harus)
Work has been resumed at Paisley and Ferguslie.(Reuter)

div.head:
THE GOBLET MONUMENT
DANGERS OF ANTI-MILITARISM.

div.p: M. Clemenceau, inaugurating the monument to René Goblet, spoke against the anti-militarist theories and asserted that France had need of young intellectual persons and soldiers to cooperate for the progress of humanity. (Harus)
4 Greeks have been murdered by a Trireo Roumanian band near Korani.(Reuter)
Herr Otto has acquired 200,000 hectares in Kilosa (German East Africa) which will be planted for cotton and rubber. Only Germans will be employed.(Harus)

div.head:
FRANCE AND MOROCCO.
A DIPLOMATIC MISSION.

div.p: M. Regnault charged with a diplomatic mission, has embarked on a cruiser here. He is Awaiting General Liautey, commander of the Oran division, and on his arrival will leave for Rabat where he will meet the Sultan.(Reuter)
A meeting of socialists held here yesterday protested very strongly against the Moroccan expedition which they declared was tempting Germany to provoke a European war.(Havas)
M. Regnanlt has arrived. (Havas)
Sir Eldon Gorst has left for Egypt.(Reuter)
The Austrian and Hungarian Governments have issued notes emphasising their mutual agreement. It is said that the note will be signed on Monday.(Hans)
Delay in the introduction of land reforms has caused an unsettled feeling among the peasants in various parts of Romania. Drought, rendering ploughing impossible, has added to the discontent.(Reuter)

The successful maneuvers carried out by 10,000 reservists in the vicinity of Athens are generally regarded as demonstrating the great progress made in the Greek army in recent years.
Similar maneuvers have taken place in the provinces.(Reuter)
The first commission of the Conference has adopted obligatory arbitrage in principle as formulated by the Anglo-American proposal.(Reuter)

div.head:
PARIS MUNICIPIAL COUNCIL.
VISIT TO LONDON.

div.p: The members of the Paris Municipal Council who are visiting London have arrived.(Reuter)
Weiss defended Roberts on the new arcoval billiard table by 14,000 to 12,634(Reuter)
M. Rostand has successfully gone through his operation.(Havas)
Prince George is to be married at Paris on the 19th ist(Havas)
Admiral Germinat has been appointed commander of the Mediterranean squadron.(Havas)

The airship left Aldershot in the forenoon and proceeded to London. It circled above Saint Paul's, visited the War Office, where it surprised the Army Councillors who rushed out to witness the spectacle, maneuvered over Buckingham Palace, and descended at the Crystal Palace where the aeronauts launched in response to a megaphone invitation. Thousands thronged the roofs and in the streets gazing at the unique sight.(Reuter)

The police have arrested 7 Armenians and seized apparatus and chemicals for the manufacture of bombs, and correspondence proving that the prisoners were working in conjunction with an Armenian society in Bulgaria. (Reuter)

div.head: "THE WHITE MAN'S BURDEN"
div.p: "In all this turmoil of racial and religious hatreds, this call for a 'white Australia,' these brutal lynohings of negroes in the Southern States, it is a little quaint that the world should have to wait for Prince Ito, the Japanese statesman, to strike the required note," says the "Star" "In an interview before his departure as Japanese Resident General in Korea he declared his willingness to work with British missionaries for building up a new Korea, and then he added this pregnant sentence: - "The thinking people of the world approve of Japan's course. What does it matter about the colour of my skin or my religious belief if I am working for the good of humanity?
Working For Humanity

"Surely there never was a more bitter irony than this. Englishmen and Americans, to name no others, have had fifteen centuries of Christian civilisation behind them, and they cannot live up to this ideal yet. The Christian missionary in India will not receive at his home the most cultured Hindu nobleman, 'the Christian ministers in the Southern States do nothing to stop their flooks from burning alive, soaked in kerosene, poor negroes who are in many cases innocent of the offences charged against them. So far from working with the coloured man for the good of humanity, the most advanced sentiment is that of the Pharisaical verses of Kipling:

Take tip the White Man's Burden, The synge Wars of pence, Fill fall the month of Famine, And bid the sickness case, And when your goal is nearest, The end for other sought, Watch Sloth and heathen Folly, Bring all your hope to nought.

"The Russo-Japanese war has perhaps partially awakened the complacency of this sort of prophet ; indeed, we do not seem to remember that Mr. Kipling has yet found words to celebrate that triumph of 'Sloth and heathen Folly' over the soldiers of the Cross. The white man has so long looked down upon 'the heathen in his blindness' that the success of Japan in the arts, in trade, and in war has been a real soul-awakener to him. He has discovered that he is not the overlord of all the earth, and we hope Prince Ito's noble words will bring some response (however shamefaced) from the professors of faith, hope, and charity in European arsenals and churches."
Ito's Ideal for Korea.

Discussing his programme, Prince Ito further said :-"The ten millions of people in Korea would become the friends of Japan more quickly if they were acquainted with the fact that my programme is directed entirely to the relief and assistance of the poorer classes by means of enactments respecting the land laws, equitable taxation, education, and justice. It is true that the Koreans themselves ) may prevent the accomplishment of our propose to give them their own system of government and their own army, but Koreans all the world over must understand, once for all, that the political supremacy of Japan in Korea will remain firmly established. We are not asking the advice of anyone regarding this policy. If the Koreans refuse to accept fair and friendly assistance, then they will, by their own act, writo annexation into history. As a nation divided in sentiment from Japan, Koren cannot stand."

div.head: THE BRITISH MIDDLE CLASSES
div.p: "The moral and civic qualities which make the British middle classes what they are, are not originally the fruit of University education or of literary education of any kind," says the "Times." "They date back to a time when duration of any sort was almost wholly confined to the clergy. They spring from moral and religious traditions, from family feeling, and from class feeling. They have been nurtured and confirmed by education, it is true, but mainly by an invention which is not that of Books. It is the struggle of life in the field, in the factory, in the counting-house, house, and on the high seas that has moulded and matured them. Mia in that struggle that these classes have learnt their independence, their self respect, their trust in each other, their enterprise, and their firmness of purpose. Book Learning and culture have been slowly and gradually added to this solid foundation."

div.head: WHITE MEN'S WAGES FOR ALIENS
div.p: "So far as we have soon-and we have diligently sought-no newspaper in England has had any solution to suggest for the yellow trouble in British Columbia," says the "New Age." "All that our journalist-state men have been able to do is to affirm with damnable iteration the first duty of all civilized Governments to keep order. But the problem is not the problem of keeping order for a few months or years, it is the problem of settling a question that is bound to arise over and over again. If the alien question were peculiar to Canada, or were only periodio in its pressure, keeping cool and relying upon police and soldiers might be a good enough policy; but the question is nothing of the kind. It is neither peculiar to Canada nor to the British Empire; it is a standing problem, and a problem of ever-growing dimensions in all parts of the world where the white tacos meet the coloured races. Canada's Treaty with Japan
Canada's Treaty with Japan.

"In the onset of British Columbia the circumstances are perhaps a little more aggravated than usual by the fact that Canada went ont of her way to beg for a share in the AngloJapanese Treaty of 1904. Only in January of this very year that Treaty was adopted and given the force of law in the Canadian dominion. By its first clause, the Japanese were specifically given the right to enter, travel, or reside in any part of the dominions and possessions of England, and thenceforward. Of course, in Canada itself. No doubt Sir Wilfrid Laurier was thinking Imperially, and reckon fing, as Imperialista so often do, without his host. Moreover, until the early spring of this year, the Japanese had never descended upon the Vancouver coasts in the hordes familiar to the more southern Pacific. But with the signing of the Treaty the current of Japanese immigrants immediately bifurcated, with the result that British Columbia is rapidly apI pronching the condition of San Francisco and the Pacific slope...

Japanese or the Chinese or the Hindus leave their native lands simply for 'les beaux yeux of the white man. These races are driven from their own lands by the same kind of pressure that drives the best of the English labourers Jabload, and declimates the countryside of Ireland and being especially gifted with the capacity for following all the excellent advice T of Samuel Smiles to our working classes having industry, thrift, and all the rest of the Jignoble virtues, they succeed in capturing the markets against the comparatively spendthrift, lazy, and incompetent European.
The Perpetual Yellow Peril.

"As for the remedy, it has been pointed out by Socialists from the year One of Socialist era. There is nothing very abstruse or meta| physical about it. ... Our remedy against alion immigration is to abolish the industries on which aliens presumably flourish by imposing a minimum wage below which no man shall soll his labour. Unless an industry can afford to pay ite workers a European rate of wages, it is the most natural thing in the world that capitalista should desire to import aliens whose standard of living approximates to the lower rate. For the life of us we cannot see either that the importing capitalists are to blame, or that the alien immigrants should be described and treated as 'rats'. If we want to preserve the Empire for white men, then we must pay whito men's wages, and nothing but white men's wages. Every industry in the Empire that pays its workers less than a white man's wage is a perpetual "yellow peril', even though no Japanese or Chinese have ever set their alien feet upon the soil."

div.head: CRUELTY TO HORSES
div.p: Marie Lutgen, former Countess du Pin de la Guérinière, now a licensed cab driver, toll horrible tales of cruelty to Paris cab-horses.

She vouches for an almost incredible story of cruelty, practised for years in the largest hackney cab stables of Paris. A wretched animal was kept to be experimented upon with different foods, or so-called foods. It was harnessed like a horse turning a merry-go round. New sorts of "fodder", such as pounded wood shavings, were given to the long-suffering beast, and it was kept going I round and round to see how much work it could do on how little of the stuff. The rations were gradually reduced in order to find out the minimum limit to which horses could be usefully starved. The cablady says the wretched animal was thus experimenter on for its entire existence, and was well known to the company's drivers, who called it the "chairman's hobby horse." She tells other diabolical stories of cabmen keeping iron tipped sticks wherewith to prod their worn ont beasts, and driving wounded bornes day after day, purpose ly whipping them on their sores. If such fiendish cruelty na this be practised, even by half-a-dozen onbren, the only thing will be to give up cabs altogether. Everyone has pitied Paris horrors, half of them lenn, weary, heart-broken judes, which when they are down wish only to die. The cab woman's conclusion is that the unfortunate Paris horse will have a better chance of a decent existence with a cabI woman than with A one man.

div.head: DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.
div.p: Our uncertain climate is responsible for many ailments, of which few entail more suffering than Rheumatism. Yet the fact is not fully recognised that Rheumatism's acute agonies are the result of a vitiated condition of the Blood, and only when the veins are replenished with new, good blood can the poisons causing Rheumatism be driven out of the system. The one great remedy capable of building up and purifying the blood is Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People; and the manner in which they cure Rheumatism is illustrated in the case of Mrs. Rooney, 51, Hayes-street, Haslingden, Lancs.

"In spite of warm clothing during changeable weather, I was attacked by Acute Rheumatism," she said, "and it threatened to ruin my constitution. The pains began in my hands, and gradually spread to my feet. All my joints became inflamed, and pains shot through my limbs and muscles day and night, nearly driving me mad. I couldn't work, and I couldn't sleep. Indeed, I could not even bear the weight of bedclothes upon my body. My hands became so contracted that I was crippled in every finger. Then my digestion was affected, and food caused sharp pains through my chest and back. The least change in the weather increased the tortures of Rheumatism, and every draught punished me. I fought hard with every means in my power to conque the Rheumatism, and besides taking medicine I applied powerful embrocations, but nothing gave hope of the least improvement. My breathing became difficult and the least excitement caused my heart to palpitte distressingly, while all my strength vanished.

Friends then advised me to take a course of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, and I bought some, though I had no hope of ever being well again. To my joy I found this wonderful medicine gradually restoring my strength. After the third box I was well on my way to health, and after the sixth box I felt a tingling through my veins, and a comfortable warmth all over my body. I slept well at night, and food no longer caused indigestion. My breathing was easy, and as I continued Dr. Williams' Pink Pills the inflammation left me, my joints grew supple, and every trace of Rheumatism vanished. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills cleared my veins of all the poisons of Rheumatism and gave me rich, pure blood."

Not only Rheumatism but all diseases resulting from bad or impoverished blood have been cured repeatedly by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People: they are invaluable in Anaemia, General Weakness, Indigestion, Eezema, Sciatica, Neuralgia, Nervous Disorders, Paralysis and Ladies' Ailments.
